title: Basketball Terminology
description: Dribble your way through this quiz about basketball terms!

questions.question: In basketball, what is a 'triple-double'?
options: Scoring thirty points
Three double-fouls in a game
Accumulating double-digit totals in three statistical categories in one game
Making three consecutive three-pointers
questions.explanation: A triple-double occurs when a player accumulates double-digit numbers (10+) in three of five statistical categories: points, rebounds, assists, steals, or blocks in a single game.

questions.question: What is a 'pick and roll' in basketball?
options: A bakery play
A defensive strategy to steal the ball
Rolling the ball on the court to start play
An offensive play where one player sets a screen and then moves toward the basket
questions.explanation: The pick and roll is a fundamental offensive play where one player sets a screen (pick) for the ball handler, then rolls toward the basket to receive a pass.

questions.question: In basketball, what does 'traveling' mean?
options: Running the fast break
Taking the team on a road trip
Moving illegally with the ball without dribbling
Passing to a teammate down the court
questions.explanation: Traveling is a violation where a player moves one or both feet illegally while holding the ball, typically by taking too many steps without dribbling.

questions.question: What is a 'fast break' in basketball?
options: A halftime break that is shorter than usual
A broken play that results in a turnover
A quick offensive transition to score before the defense is set
A quick timeout
questions.explanation: A fast break is a quick offensive attack where a team pushes the ball up the court rapidly to score before the opposing defense has time to set up.

questions.question: In basketball, what is the 'paint' (or 'the key')?
options: The line marking three-point range
The center circle
The colored area on the court near each basket
The bench area
questions.explanation: The paint (also called the key or lane) is the rectangular area on the court extending from the free-throw line to the baseline, typically painted a different color.

questions.question: What is a 'sixth man' in basketball?
options: A player who plays all six positions
The referee
The best substitute player who comes off the bench first
An illegal extra player on the court
questions.explanation: The sixth man is the first substitute to enter the game off the bench, often a key player who provides energy and scoring. The NBA even awards a Sixth Man of the Year award.

questions.question: In basketball, what is an 'alley-oop'?
options: A behind-the-back dribble
A shot from halfcourt
A defensive block
A pass near the basket that a teammate catches in mid-air and scores
questions.explanation: An alley-oop is a play where one player throws the ball near the basket and a teammate leaps, catches it in mid-air, and immediately scores, usually with a dunk.

questions.question: What does 'double dribble' mean in basketball?
options: Bouncing the ball twice on one dribble
Dribbling with both hands simultaneously
Picking up the ball then dribbling again, or dribbling with both hands
Dribbling past two defenders
questions.explanation: A double dribble is a violation that occurs when a player dribbles with both hands simultaneously or stops dribbling and then starts again.

questions.question: In basketball, what is a 'flagrant foul'?
options: A minor reaching foul
A foul at the end of the game
An unnecessarily excessive or violent contact foul
A foul committed while waving a flag
questions.explanation: A flagrant foul involves unnecessary and/or excessive contact with an opponent, penalized with free throws and possession of the ball, or even ejection for severe cases.

questions.question: What is a 'box out' in basketball?
options: A defensive formation resembling a box
Passing to a player outside the three-point line
Positioning oneself between an opponent and the basket to gain a rebounding advantage
Checking out of the game
questions.explanation: Boxing out is a rebounding technique where a player positions their body between an opponent and the basket after a shot, using their back and legs to maintain position for the rebound.

questions.question: In basketball, what is a 'crossover' dribble?
options: Quickly switching the ball from one hand to the other to change direction
Passing the ball over a defender
Dribbling across the halfcourt line
A dribble that crosses the free-throw line
questions.explanation: A crossover is a dribbling move where the ball handler quickly bounces the ball from one hand to the other in front of the body, changing direction to beat a defender.

questions.question: What does 'and-one' mean in basketball?
options: Making a basket while being fouled, earning a free throw attempt
Adding one minute to the game clock
A one-on-one challenge
The first overtime period
questions.explanation: An and-one occurs when a player makes a basket while being fouled, earning the points for the basket plus one free throw attempt for a potential three-point play.

questions.question: In basketball, what is the 'shot clock'?
options: A clock that shows how much time remains in the game
A device that measures shot speed
A buzzer that sounds when a shot is made
A timer that limits how long a team can possess the ball before shooting
questions.explanation: The shot clock is a timer (24 seconds in the NBA) that limits how long the offensive team can possess the ball before attempting a shot, promoting faster play.

questions.question: What is a 'Euro step' in basketball?
options: A dance move performed during celebrations
A step used only by European players
A two-step move where the player steps one direction then quickly the other to evade a defender
A step-back three-pointer
questions.explanation: The Euro step is a move where the ball handler takes a step in one direction and then quickly takes a second step in the opposite direction to evade a defender on the way to the basket.

questions.question: In basketball, what is a 'technical foul'?
options: A foul during a free throw
A foul for unsportsmanlike conduct, such as arguing with officials
A foul committed in the technical area
A foul for improper technique
questions.explanation: A technical foul is assessed for unsportsmanlike behavior such as arguing with referees, taunting, or other conduct violations, resulting in free throws for the opposing team.
